subsc: Primary education,Secondary education,Vocational training,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, though only modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons highlight the
            successful measure taken in the delegation of school
            construction to professional management, since government
            construction services, and the recruitment of qualified
            workers, does not provide good performance, nor incentives
            to guarantee it. However, had the works and goods to be
            procured been a condition for appraisal, i.e., launching
            tenders early on, with bid evaluation as a condition for
            credit effectiveness, transparency and early implementation
            would have been ensured. Moreover, given the weak
            implementation capacity, a careful assessment of
            implications on the work load becomes essential to prevent
            serious delays. Such a situation would have considerably
            been relieved, had procurement of works and goods been
            front-end loaded, allowing extra time to improve core
            skills. As for the capacity of communities (and families) to
            finance education, it should be carefully assessed and
            monitored, as well as other contributions likely to be made
            - e.g., to primary health care - since, similarly, a
            sustainable community response will likely depend on their
            participation in management responsibilities. Regrettably,
            such arrangements that prod civil society's role in the
            management of funds, are not yet clear. Monitoring criteria
            should ensure that priority sector work is implemented,
            particularly in the transition from project lending to
            budget support.
